Award.AwardTitle: CNH: A Social-Ecological Analysis of Nitrogen in Agricultural Systems of the Upper Midwest
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nitrogen loss from corn farming in the Midwest is a major cause of water pollution and greenhouse gas emission. Focusing on farms in Iowa, Illinois, and Michigan, this project will address important gaps in our current understanding of the links between the decisions of corn farmers and the quality of water and air in the region. Researchers will refine previous work on nitrogen loss to take variability within farm fields into account, identify the factors that influence the decisions of farmers about fertilizer use, and develop an integrated, quantitative model that couples the natural dynamics of nitrogen cycling with the social and economic dynamics of farming.

Results from this project will help farmers and policy makers evaluate alternative ways to reduce water pollution and greenhouse gas emissions from Midwestern row crops. A Nitrogen Roundtable will bring researchers, managers, and stakeholders together, and the project will engage K-12 educators to disseminate research results to the public. The model to be produced is expected to provide a new decision-support tool for more sustainable agriculture in the U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined the biophysical and social factors driving excess nitrogen loss from corn production systems in the Upper Midwest of the United States. Nitrogen loss not only costs farmers money, but contributes to water pollution and the release of nitrous oxide, a powerful greenhouse gas. The goal was to better understand nitrogen fertilizer decisions, examine drivers and rates of nitrogen loss, and provide information that could assist efforts to maximize efficiency and reduce pollution. Research methods included mail surveys, personal interviews, field experiments, and aerial analysis.

Findings contributed to theory development and new understandings in multiple academic disciplines including environmental and rural sociology, economics, agronomy, and biogeochemistry. Publications in these disciplinary areas increased knowledge about farmer decision-making and the biophysical aspects of nitrogen loss. In addition, this study contributed to a growing body of interdisciplinary work in coupled natural and human systems.

Findings from this study have direct implications for policy and management. Results indicate that for most corn farmers, nitrogen management is seen as complex and filled with uncertainty due to weather, variable recommendations, and volatile crop and input prices. Many farmers apply nitrogen at rates above those generally recommended in university and extension standards and this results in increased rates of nitrogen loss. Farmers use of nitrogen efficiency practices and technologies remains low, with less than half of farmers utilizing precision techniques such as variable rate nitrogen application or remote sensing. Non-adopting farmers generally perceive these practices to be complex, difficult to implement, expensive, and time-intensive. In addition, corn farmers use and trust nitrogen fertilizer information and recommendations from fertilizer and seed companies more than from universities and extension services. This context results in decisions to apply higher rates of nitrogen fertilizer. This suggests that environmental efforts need to focus on increasing trust and confidence in university recommendations and extension services, developing partnerships with seed and fertilizer companies to reduce nitrogen loss, and making efficiency technologies and tools more affordable and easier to adopt.

This project included workshops with agricultural producers and professionals and the development of an online nitrogen rate calculator. The findings from this study have been published widely in academic journals as well as journals for agricultural professions. These findings identify drivers of nitrogen loss as well as opportunities to increase efficiency.
